Introduction.text: A galaxy is a system of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), [stellar [remnants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supernova_remnant)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_remnant), [interstellar gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_medium), [dust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmic_dust), and [[dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter) bound together by [gravity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravity). The word is derived from the [Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_philosophy) galaxias (γαλαξίας), literally 'milky', a reference to the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) galaxy that contains the [Solar System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Portal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:[Astronomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Astronomy)):Solar_System). [Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies), averaging an estimated 100 million [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), range in size from [dwarfs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy) with less than a thousand [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), to the [[largest galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_galaxies) known](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_galaxies) – [supergiants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type-cD_galaxy) with one hundred [trillion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/10%5E12) [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), each orbiting its galaxy's [center of mass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_of_mass). Most of the mass in a typical galaxy is in the form of [[dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter), with [only a few](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_galaxies#Named_galaxies) percent of that mass visible in the form of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) and [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula). [Supermassive [black holes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hole)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole) are a common feature at the centres of galaxies. [Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies) are categorised according to their visual [morphology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphology_(astronomy)) as [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy), [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy), or [irregular](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy#Common_dwarf_galaxy_types). The [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) is an example of a [[spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_galaxy). It is estimated that there are between 200 billion (2×1011) to 2 [trillion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/10%5E12) galaxies in the [observable [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observable_universe). Most galaxies are 1,000 to 100,000 [parsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec) in diameter (approximately 3,000 to 300,000 [light years](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light_year)) and are separated by distances in the order of millions of [parsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec) (or [megaparsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec#Megaparsecs_and_gigaparsecs)). For comparison, the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) has a diameter of at least 26,800 [parsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec) (87,400 [ly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light-year)) and is separated from the [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy), its nearest large neighbour, by just over 750,000 [parsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec) (2.5 million [ly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light-year)). The space between galaxies is filled with a tenuous gas (the [intergalactic medium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intergalactic_space)) with an average density of less than one [atom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atom) per cubic metre. Most galaxies are gravitationally organised into [groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy_group), [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies) and [superclusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supercluster). The [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) is part of the [Local Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Group), which it dominates along with the [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy). The [group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy_group) is part of the [Virgo Supercluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgo_Supercluster). At the [largest scale](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large-scale_structure_of_the_Cosmos), these associations are generally arranged into [sheets and filaments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy_filament) surrounded by immense [voids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Void_(astronomy)). Both the [Local Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Group) and the [Virgo Supercluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgo_Supercluster) are contained in a much larger cosmic structure named [Laniakea](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laniakea_Supercluster).

P.text: The word galaxy was borrowed via [French](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_language) and [Medieval Latin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medieval_Latin) from the [Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_philosophy) term for the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way), galaxías (kúklos) γαλαξίας (κύκλος) 'milky (circle)', named after its appearance as a milky band of light in the sky. In [Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_philosophy) mythology, [Zeus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zeus) places his son, born by a mortal woman, the infant [Heracles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heracles), on [Hera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera)'s breast while she is asleep so the baby will drink [her divine milk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milk_of_Hera) and thus become immortal. [Hera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hera) wakes up while breastfeeding and then realises she is nursing an unknown baby: she pushes the baby away, some of her milk spills, and it produces the band of light known as the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way). In the astronomical literature, the capitalised word "Galaxy" is often used to refer to the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) galaxy, to distinguish it from the other galaxies in the [observable [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observable_universe). The English term [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) can be traced back to a story by [Geoffrey Chaucer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geoffrey_Chaucer) c. 1380:  See yonder, lo, the Galaxyë Which men clepeth the Milky Wey, For hit is whyt. [Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies) were initially discovered telescopically and were known as [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula). Most 18th- to 19th-century astronomers considered them as either unresolved star [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies) or anagalactic [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula), and were just thought of as a part of the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way), but their true composition and natures remained a mystery. Observations using larger telescopes of a few nearby bright galaxies, like the [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy), began resolving them into huge conglomerations of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), but based simply on the apparent faintness and sheer population of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), the true distances of these objects placed them well beyond the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way). For this reason they were popularly called island universes, but this term quickly fell into disuse, as the word [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe) implied the entirety of existence. Instead, they became known simply as galaxies.

Millions of galaxies have been catalogued, but [only a few](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_galaxies#Named_galaxies) have well-established names, such as the [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy), the [[Magellanic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magellanic_spiral) Clouds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magellanic_Clouds), the [Whirlpool Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whirlpool_Galaxy), and the [Sombrero Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sombrero_Galaxy). Astronomers work with numbers from certain catalogues, such as the [Messier catalogue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_catalogue), the NGC ([New General Catalogue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_General_Catalogue)), the IC ([Index Catalogue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Index_Catalogue)), the CGCG ([Catalogue of [Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies) and of Clusters of [Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catalogue_of_Galaxies_and_of_Clusters_of_Galaxies)), the MCG ([Morphological Catalogue of [Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphological_Catalogue_of_Galaxies)), the UGC ([Uppsala General Catalogue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uppsala_General_Catalogue) of [Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies)), and the PGC ([Catalogue of Principal [Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catalogue_of_Principal_Galaxies), also known as LEDA). All the well-known galaxies appear in one or more of these catalogues but each time under a different number. For example, [Messier 109](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_109) (or "M109") is a [[spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_galaxy) having the number 109 in the catalogue of Messier.  It also has the designations NGC 3992, UGC 6937, CGCG 269–023, MCG +09-20-044, and PGC 37617 (or LEDA 37617), among others.  Millions of fainter galaxies are known by their identifiers in [sky surveys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sky_surveys) such as the [Sloan Digital Sky Survey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sloan_Digital_Sky_Survey).

[Greek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_philosophy) philosopher [Democritus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democritus) (450–370 BCE) proposed that the bright band on the night sky known as the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) might consist of distant [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star). [Aristotle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle) (384–322 BCE), however, believed the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) was caused by "the ignition of the fiery exhalation of some [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) that were large, numerous and close together" and that the "ignition takes place in the upper part of the [atmosphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmosphere), in the [region of the World that is continuous with the heavenly motions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sublunary_sphere)." [Neoplatonist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoplatonism) philosopher [Olympiodorus the Younger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olympiodorus_the_Younger) (c. 495–570 CE) was critical of this view, arguing that if the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) was [sublunary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sublunary) (situated between Earth and the [Moon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon)) it should appear different at different times and places on Earth, and that it should have [parallax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallax), which it did not. In his view, the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) was celestial. According to Mohani Mohamed, [Arabian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomy_in_the_medieval_Islamic_world) astronomer [Ibn al-Haytham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibn_al-Haytham) (965–1037) made the first attempt at observing and measuring the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way)'s [parallax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallax), and he thus "determined that because the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) had no [parallax](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallax), it must be remote from the Earth, not belonging to the [atmosphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmosphere)." [Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_people) astronomer [al-Biruni](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Biruni) (973–1048) proposed the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) galaxy was "a collection of countless fragments of the nature of nebulous [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star)." [Andalusian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Al-Andalus) astronomer [Avempace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avempace) (d. 1138) proposed that it was composed of many [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) that almost touched one another, and appeared to be a continuous image due to the effect of [refraction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Refraction) from [sublunary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sublunary) material, citing his observation of the [conjunction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjunction_(astronomy_and_astrology)) of Jupiter and Mars as evidence of this occurring when two objects were near. In the 14th century, Syrian-born [Ibn Qayyim al-Jawziyya](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ibn_Qayyim_al-Jawziyya) proposed the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) galaxy was "a myriad of tiny [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) packed together in the sphere of the fixed [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star)."  Actual proof of the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) consisting of many [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) came in 1610 when the Italian astronomer [Galileo Galilei](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galileo_Galilei) used a [telescope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_telescope) to study it and discovered it was composed of a huge number of faint [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star). In 1750, English astronomer [Thomas Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Wright_(astronomer)), in his An Original Theory or New Hypothesis of the Universe, correctly speculated that it might be a rotating body of a huge number of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) held together by [gravitational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitation) forces, akin to the [Solar System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Portal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:[Astronomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Astronomy)):Solar_System) but on a much larger scale, and that the resulting disk of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) could be seen as a band on the sky from a perspective inside it. In his 1755 treatise, [Immanuel Kant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immanuel_Kant) elaborated on Wright's idea about the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way)'s structure.  The first project to describe the shape of the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) and the position of the Sun was undertaken by [William Herschel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Herschel) in 1785 by counting the number of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) in different regions of the sky. He produced a diagram of the shape of the galaxy with the [Solar System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Portal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:[Astronomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Astronomy)):Solar_System) close to the center. Using a refined approach, [Kapteyn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jacobus_Kapteyn) in 1920 arrived at the picture of a small (diameter about 15 [kiloparsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec#Parsecs_and_kiloparsecs)) ellipsoid galaxy with the Sun close to the center. A different method by [Harlow Shapley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harlow_Shapley) based on the cataloguing of globular [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies) led to a radically different picture: a flat disk with diameter approximately 70 [kiloparsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec#Parsecs_and_kiloparsecs) and the Sun far from the centre. Both analyses failed to take into account the [absorption of light](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extinction_(astronomy)) by interstellar [dust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmic_dust) present in the [galactic plane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_plane); but after [Robert Julius Trumpler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Julius_Trumpler) quantified this effect in 1930 by studying open [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies), the present picture of the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) galaxy emerged.

A few galaxies outside the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) are visible on a [dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) night to the [unaided eye](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naked_eye), including the [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy), [Large [Magellanic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magellanic_spiral) Cloud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_Magellanic_Cloud), [Small [Magellanic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magellanic_spiral) Cloud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Small_Magellanic_Cloud), and the [Triangulum Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangulum_Galaxy). In the 10th century, [Persian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persian_people) astronomer [Abd al-Rahman al-Sufi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abd_al-Rahman_al-Sufi) made the earliest recorded identification of the [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy), describing it as a "small cloud". In 964, he probably mentioned the [Large [Magellanic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magellanic_spiral) Cloud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Large_Magellanic_Cloud) in his [Book of Fixed [Stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portal:Stars)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Book_of_Fixed_Stars), referring to "Al Bakr of the southern Arabs", since at a [declination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Declination) of about 70° south it was not visible where he lived. It was not well known to Europeans until [Magellan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ferdinand_Magellan)'s voyage in the 16th century. The [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) was later independently noted by [Simon Marius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simon_Marius) in 1612. In 1734, philosopher [Emanuel Swedenborg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emanuel_Swedenborg) in his Principia speculated that there might be other galaxies outside that were formed into galactic [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies) that were minuscule parts of the [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe) that extended far beyond what could be seen. These views "are remarkably close to the present-day views of the cosmos." In 1745, [Pierre Louis Maupertuis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Louis_Maupertuis) conjectured that some [nebula](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula)-like objects were collections of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) with unique properties, including a [glow exceeding the light](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Relativistic_jets) its [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) produced on their own, and repeated [Johannes Hevelius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Hevelius)'s view that the bright spots were massive and flattened due to their rotation. In 1750, [Thomas Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Wright_(astronomer)) correctly speculated that the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) was a flattened disk of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), and that some of the [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula) visible in the night sky might be separate Milky Ways.  Toward the end of the 18th century, [Charles Messier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Messier) compiled a [catalog](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_object) containing the 109 brightest celestial objects having nebulous appearance. Subsequently, [William Herschel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Herschel) assembled a [catalog](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_object) of 5,000 [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula). In 1845, [Lord Rosse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_Parsons,_3rd_Earl_of_Rosse) examined the [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula) catalogued by Herschel and observed the [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) structure of [[Messier object](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_object) M51](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whirlpool_Galaxy), now known as the [Whirlpool Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whirlpool_Galaxy). In 1912, [Vesto M. Slipher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vesto_M._Slipher) made spectrographic studies of the brightest [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula) to determine their composition. Slipher discovered that the [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula) have high [Doppler shifts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doppler_shift), indicating that they are moving at a rate exceeding the velocity of the [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) he had measured. He found that the majority of these [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula) are moving away from us. In 1917, [Heber Doust Curtis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heber_Doust_Curtis) observed nova [S Andromedae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S_Andromedae) within the "Great [Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Nebula", as the [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy), [Messier object](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_object) [M31](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy), was then known. Searching the photographic record, he found 11 more [novae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nova). Curtis noticed that these [novae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nova) were, on average, 10 [magnitudes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnitude_(astronomy)) fainter than those that occurred within this galaxy. As a result, he was able to come up with a distance estimate of 150,000 [parsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec). He became a proponent of the so-called "island universes" hypothesis, which holds that [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula) are actually independent galaxies. In 1920 a debate took place between [Harlow Shapley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harlow_Shapley) and [Heber Curtis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heber_Curtis), the [Great Debate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Debate_(astronomy)), concerning the nature of the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way), [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula), and the dimensions of the [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe). To support his claim that the Great [Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Nebula is an external galaxy, Curtis noted the appearance of [dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) lanes resembling the [dust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmic_dust) clouds in the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way), as well as the significant Doppler shift. In 1922, the [Estonian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estonia) astronomer [Ernst Öpik](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ernst_%C3%96pik) gave a distance determination that supported the theory that the [Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Nebula is indeed a distant extra-galactic object. Using the new 100-inch [Mt. Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Wilson_Observatory) [telescope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_telescope), [Edwin [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edwin_Hubble) was able to resolve the outer parts of some [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula) as collections of individual [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) and identified some [Cepheid variables](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cepheid_variable), thus allowing him to estimate the distance to the [nebulae](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nebula): they were far too distant to be part of the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way). In 1926 [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) produced a classification of galactic [morphology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphology_(astronomy)) that is used to this day.

Advances in astronomy have always been driven by technology. After centuries of success in [optical astronomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_astronomy), recent decades have seen major progress in other regions of the [electromagnetic spectrum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetic_spectrum). The [dust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmic_dust) present in the [interstellar medium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_medium) is opaque to visual light. It is more transparent to [far-[infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Far_infrared_astronomy), which can be used to observe the interior regions of giant [molecular clouds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_cloud) and [galactic cores](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulge_(astronomy)) in great detail. Infrared is also used to observe distant, [red-shifted](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redshift) galaxies that were formed much earlier. Water vapor and [carbon dioxide](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbon_dioxide) absorb a number of useful portions of the [infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared) spectrum, so high-altitude or space-based telescopes are used for [[infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared) astronomy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared_astronomy). The first non-visual study of galaxies, particularly [active galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_galaxy), was made using [radio frequencies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_astronomy). The Earth's [atmosphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmosphere) is nearly transparent to radio between 5 [MHz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hertz) and 30 GHz. The [ionosphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ionosphere) blocks signals below this range. Large radio [interferometers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interferometry) have been used to map the active jets emitted from active nuclei. [Ultraviolet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UV_astronomy) and [X-ray telescopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-ray_astronomy) can observe highly energetic galactic phenomena. [Ultraviolet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UV_astronomy) flares are sometimes observed when a star in a distant galaxy is torn apart from the tidal forces of a nearby black hole. The distribution of hot gas in galactic [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies) can be mapped by X-rays. The existence of supermassive [black holes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hole) at the cores of galaxies was confirmed through X-ray astronomy.

In 1944, [Hendrik van de Hulst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hendrik_C._van_de_Hulst) predicted that [microwave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microwave) radiation with [wavelength of 21 cm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen_line) would be detectable from interstellar atomic [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) gas; and in 1951 it was observed. This radiation is not affected by [dust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmic_dust) absorption, and so its Doppler shift can be used to map the motion of the gas in this galaxy. These observations led to the hypothesis of a rotating [bar structure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barred_spiral_galaxy) in the center of this galaxy. With improved [radio telescopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_telescope), [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen) gas could also be traced in other galaxies. In the 1970s, [Vera Rubin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vera_Rubin) uncovered a discrepancy between observed galactic [rotation speed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy_rotation_curve) and that predicted by the visible mass of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) and gas. Today, the galaxy rotation problem is thought to be explained by the presence of large quantities of unseen [[dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter). Beginning in the 1990s, the [[Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) Space Telescope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) yielded improved observations. Among other things, its data helped establish that the missing [[dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter) in this galaxy could not consist solely of inherently faint and small [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star). The [[Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) Deep [Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_galaxy)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Deep_Field), an extremely long exposure of a relatively empty part of the sky, provided evidence that there are about 125 billion (1.25×1011) galaxies in the [observable [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observable_universe). Improved technology in detecting the [spectra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetic_spectrum) invisible to humans ([radio telescopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_telescope), [infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared) cameras, and [x-ray telescopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-ray_astronomy)) allows detection of other galaxies that are not detected by [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope). Particularly, surveys in the [Zone of Avoidance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zone_of_Avoidance) (the region of sky blocked at visible-light wavelengths by the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way)) have revealed a number of new galaxies. A 2016 study published in [The Astrophysical Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Astrophysical_Journal), led by [Christopher Conselice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_Conselice) of the [University of Nottingham](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Nottingham), used 20 years of [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) images to estimate that the [observable [universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observable_universe) contained at least two [trillion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/10%5E12) (2×1012) galaxies. However, later observations with the [New Horizons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Horizons) space probe from outside the [zodiacal light](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light) reduced this to roughly 200 billion (2×1011).

[Galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/[Category](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Galaxies):Galaxies) come in three main types: ellipticals, spirals, and irregulars. A slightly more extensive description of galaxy types based on their appearance is given by the [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) sequence. Since the [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) sequence is entirely based upon visual morphological type (shape), it may miss certain important characteristics of galaxies such as [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation) rate in [[starburst](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starburst_(astronomy)) galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starburst_galaxy) and activity in the cores of [active galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_galaxy). Many galaxies are thought to contain a [supermassive black hole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole) at their center. This includes the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way), whose core region is called the [Galactic Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_Center).

The [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) classification system rates [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) galaxies on the basis of their ellipticity, ranging from E0, being nearly spherical, up to E7, which is highly elongated. These galaxies have an [ellipsoidal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellipsoid) profile, giving them an [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) appearance regardless of the viewing angle. Their appearance shows little structure and they typically have relatively little [interstellar matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_medium). Consequently, these galaxies also have a low portion of open [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies) and a reduced rate of new [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation). Instead, they are dominated by generally older, more evolved [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) that are orbiting the common center of [gravity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravity) in random directions. The [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) contain low abundances of heavy elements because [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation) ceases after the initial burst. In this sense they have some similarity to the much smaller globular [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies).

The [largest galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_galaxies) are the [type-[cD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type-cD_galaxy) galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type-cD_galaxy). First described in 1964 by a paper by Thomas A. Matthews and others, they are a subtype of the more general class of D galaxies, which are giant [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) galaxies, except that they are much larger. They are popularly known as the supergiant [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) galaxies and constitute the largest and most luminous galaxies known. These galaxies feature a central [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) nucleus with an extensive, faint halo of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) extending to megaparsec scales. The profile of their surface brightnesses as a function of their radius (or distance from their cores) falls off more slowly than their smaller counterparts. The [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation) of these [cD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Type-cD_galaxy) galaxies remains an active area of research, but the leading model is that they are the result of the mergers of smaller galaxies in the environments of dense [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies), or even those outside of [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies) with random overdensities. These processes are the mechanisms that drive the [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation) of fossil [groups](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy_group) or fossil [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies), where a large, relatively isolated, supergiant [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) resides in the middle of the [cluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy_cluster) and are surrounded by an extensive cloud of X-rays as the residue of these galactic collisions. Another older model posits the phenomenon of [cooling flow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooling_flow), where the heated gases in [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies) collapses towards their centers as they cool, forming [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) in the process, a phenomenon observed in [clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clusters_of_galaxies) such as [Perseus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perseus_Cluster), and more recently in the [Phoenix Cluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phoenix_Cluster).

A shell galaxy is a type of [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) galaxy where the [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) in its halo are arranged in concentric shells. About one-tenth of [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) galaxies have a shell-like structure, which has never been observed in [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies. These structures are thought to develop when a larger galaxy absorbs a smaller companion galaxy—that as the two galaxy centers approach, they start to oscillate around a center point, and the oscillation creates [gravitational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitation) ripples forming the shells of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), similar to ripples spreading on water. For example, galaxy [NGC 3923](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NGC_3923) has over 20 shells.

[Spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_spiral_galaxies) galaxies resemble spiraling [pinwheels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pinwheel_(toy)). Though the [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) and other visible material contained in such a galaxy lie mostly on a plane, the majority of mass in [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies exists in a roughly spherical halo of [[dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter) which extends beyond the visible component, as demonstrated by the universal rotation curve concept. [Spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_spiral_galaxies) galaxies consist of a rotating disk of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) and [interstellar medium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_medium), along with a central [bulge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulge_(astronomy)) of generally older [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star). Extending outward from the [bulge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulge_(astronomy)) are relatively bright arms. In the [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) classification scheme, [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies are listed as type S, followed by a letter (a, b, or c) which indicates the degree of tightness of the [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms and the size of the central [bulge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bulge_(astronomy)). An Sa galaxy has tightly wound, poorly defined arms and possesses a relatively large core region. At the other extreme, an Sc galaxy has open, well-defined arms and a small core region. A galaxy with poorly defined arms is sometimes referred to as a [flocculent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flocculent_spiral_galaxy) [[spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_galaxy); in contrast to the [grand design](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_design_spiral_galaxy) [[spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_galaxy) that has prominent and well-defined [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms. The speed in which a galaxy rotates is thought to correlate with the flatness of the disc as some [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies have thick bulges, while others are thin and dense.  In [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies, the [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms do have the shape of approximate [logarithmic spirals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logarithmic_spiral), a pattern that can be theoretically shown to result from a disturbance in a uniformly rotating mass of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star). Like the [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star), the [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms rotate around the center, but they do so with constant [angular velocity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angular_velocity). The [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms are thought to be areas of high-density matter, or "[density waves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Density_wave_theory)". As [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) move through an arm, the space velocity of each stellar system is modified by the [gravitational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravitation) force of the higher density. (The velocity returns to normal after the [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) depart on the other side of the arm.) This effect is akin to a "wave" of slowdowns moving along a highway full of moving cars. The arms are visible because the high density facilitates [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation), and therefore they harbor many bright and young [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star).

A majority of [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies, including the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way) galaxy, have a linear, bar-shaped band of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) that extends outward to either side of the core, then merges into the [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arm structure. In the [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) classification scheme, these are designated by an SB, followed by a lower-case letter (a, b or c) which indicates the form of the [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms (in the same manner as the categorization of normal [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies). Bars are thought to be temporary structures that can occur as a result of a density wave radiating outward from the core, or else due to a [tidal interaction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_tide) with another galaxy. Many [barred](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barred_irregular_galaxy) [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies are active, possibly as a result of gas being channeled into the core along the arms. Our own galaxy, the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way), is a large disk-shaped [barred](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barred_irregular_galaxy)-[[spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_galaxy) about 30 [kiloparsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec#Parsecs_and_kiloparsecs) in diameter and a kiloparsec thick. It contains about two hundred billion (2×1011) [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) and has a total mass of about six hundred billion (6×1011) times the mass of the Sun.

Recently, researchers described galaxies called super-luminous spirals. They are very large with an upward diameter of 437,000 [light-years](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light-year) (compared to the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way)'s 87,400 light-year diameter). With a mass of 340 billion [solar masses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_mass), they generate a significant amount of ultraviolet and mid-[infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared) light. They are thought to have an increased [star [formation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_formation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_formation) rate around 30 times faster than the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way).

[[Peculiar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peculiar_galaxy) galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peculiar_galaxy) are galactic formations that develop unusual properties due to [tidal interactions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_tide) with other galaxies. A [ring galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_galaxy) has a ring-like structure of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) and [interstellar medium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_medium) surrounding a bare core. A [ring galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_galaxy) is thought to occur when a smaller galaxy passes through the core of a [[spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_galaxy). Such an event may have affected the [[Andromeda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy) Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy), as it displays a multi-ring-like structure when viewed in [infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared) radiation. A [lenticular galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lenticular_galaxy) is an [intermediate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intermediate_spiral_galaxy) form that has properties of both [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) and [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) galaxies. These are categorized as [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) type S0, and they possess ill-defined [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) arms with an [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) halo of [stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star) ([[barred](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barred_irregular_galaxy) lenticular galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barred_lenticular_galaxy) receive [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) classification SB0). [[Irregular](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irregular_galaxy) galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irregular_galaxy) are galaxies that can not be readily classified into an [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_elliptical_galaxy) or [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_spiral_galaxy) [morphology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morphology_(astronomy)). An Irr-I galaxy has some structure but does not align cleanly with the [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) classification scheme. Irr-II galaxies do not possess any structure that resembles a [Hubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) classification, and may have been disrupted. Nearby examples of (dwarf) [irregular](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_galaxy#Common_dwarf_galaxy_types) galaxies include the [[Magellanic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magellanic_spiral) Clouds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magellanic_Clouds). A [dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) or "ultra diffuse" galaxy is an extremely-low-luminosity galaxy. It may be the same size as the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way), but have a visible star count only one percent of the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way)'s. Multiple mechanisms for producing this type of galaxy have been proposed, and it is possible that different [dark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_galaxy) galaxies formed by different means. One candidate explanation for the low luminosity is that the galaxy lost its star-forming gas at an early stage, resulting in old stellar populations.
